content:
Hi!

import Mathlib

def cyclotomic_degree_real_2 (n : ℕ) :=
    let φ : ℝ := 2 * Real.pi / n
    let α : ℂ := Complex.exp (φ * Complex.I)
    let β : ℂ := Real.cos φ

    let ℚ_in_ℂ := Subfield.closure {(1 : Complex)}
    let F := Subfield.closure (ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {α})
    let G := Subfield.closure (ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β})

    let h1 : (G ≤ F) := by
        have h2 : (((ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β}) : Set ℂ) ⊆ (↑F : Set ℂ))
            sorry
        sorry
    sorry

Here I get

function expected at
↑ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β} ⊆ ↑F
term has type
Prop

Why can't I 'have' a Prop?
You're missing :=, so the type it finds is (((ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β}) : Set ℂ) ⊆ (↑F : Set ℂ)) sorry

Daniel Weber said:

You're missing :=, so the type it finds is (((ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β}) : Set ℂ) ⊆ (↑F : Set ℂ)) sorry

Thank you!

                have h4 : α ∈ F
                .   have h5 : α ∈ (↑ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {α} : Set ℂ)
                    .   apply Set.mem_union_right
                        exact Set.mem_singleton α
                    apply Subfield.subset_closure
                    exact h5

                have h5 : α⁻¹ ∈ F
                .   apply Subfield.inv_mem'
                    exact h4

                have h6 : α + α⁻¹ ∈ F
                .   apply Subfield.add_mem
                    exact h4
                    exact h5

Here is a segment of other code I've written, and I thought the troublesome line has the same form. Where should I put :=? Also where can I find documentation for the tactics?

Replace the first one by

                have h4 : α ∈ F := by
Hopefully you can guess how to fix the other ones :smile:
The weird thing is, other ones didn't complain. Only the first one I posted at the top complained.

Yaël Dillies said:

Replace the first one by

                have h4 : α ∈ F := by

Thanks. Oh, I figured it out. It seems '.' replaces ':= by'.
(The full code is)

import Mathlib

def cyclotomic_degree_real_2 (n : ℕ) :=
    let φ : ℝ := 2 * Real.pi / n
    let α : ℂ := Complex.exp (φ * Complex.I)
    let β : ℂ := Real.cos φ

    let ℚ_in_ℂ := Subfield.closure {(1 : Complex)}
    let F := Subfield.closure (ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {α})
    let G := Subfield.closure (ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β})

    let h1 : (G ≤ F) := by
        have h2 : (ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {β} : Set ℂ) ⊆ (↑F : Set ℂ)
        .   apply Set.union_subset_iff.mpr
            apply And.intro
            case left =>
                unfold F
                have h3 : (ℚ_in_ℂ : Set ℂ) ⊆ (ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {α} : Set ℂ)
                apply Set.subset_union_left
                apply subset_trans h3
                apply Subfield.subset_closure

            case right =>
                unfold F
                apply Set.singleton_subset_iff.mpr
                have h3 : β = (α + α⁻¹) / 2
                .   unfold β
                    have h4 : α⁻¹ = Complex.exp (-φ * Complex.I)
                    .   have h5 : α * Complex.exp (-φ * Complex.I) = 1
                        .   unfold α
                            rw [← Complex.exp_add]
                            ring
                            exact Complex.exp_zero
                        have h6 : α ≠ 0
                        .   by_contra h7
                            rw [h7] at h5
                            ring_nf at h5
                            have h8 : ¬ ((0 : ℂ) ≠ 1)
                            .   apply not_ne_iff.mpr
                                exact h5
                            have h9 : (0 : ℂ) ≠ 1
                            .   exact zero_ne_one
                            exact (h8 h9)
                        have h7 : α * α⁻¹ = 1
                        .   apply DivisionRing.mul_inv_cancel
                            exact h6
                        have h8 : α * α⁻¹ = α * Complex.exp (-φ * Complex.I)
                        .   apply Eq.trans
                            exact h7
                            exact (eq_comm.mp h5)
                        have h9 : α⁻¹ * (α * α⁻¹) = α⁻¹ * (α * Complex.exp (-φ * Complex.I))
                        .   rw [h8]
                        conv at h9 =>
                            congr
                            rw [← mul_assoc]
                            lhs
                            rw [mul_comm]
                            rfl
                            rw [← mul_assoc]
                            lhs
                            rw [mul_comm]
                            rfl
                        rw [h7, one_mul, one_mul] at h9
                        exact h9
                    rw [h4]
                    unfold α
                    repeat rw [← Complex.cos_add_sin_I]
                    rw [Complex.ofReal_cos]
                    simp
                    ring
                rw [h3]
                have h4 : α ∈ F
                .   have h5 : α ∈ (↑ℚ_in_ℂ ∪ {α} : Set ℂ)
                    .   apply Set.mem_union_right
                        exact Set.mem_singleton α
                    apply Subfield.subset_closure
                    exact h5

                have h5 : α⁻¹ ∈ F
                .   apply Subfield.inv_mem'
                    exact h4

                have h6 : α + α⁻¹ ∈ F
                .   apply Subfield.add_mem
                    exact h4
                    exact h5

                apply Subfield.div_mem
                exact h6

                apply Subfield.subset_closure
                apply (Set.mem_union 2 ↑ℚ_in_ℂ {α}).mpr
                apply Or.inl

                have h7 : 1 ∈ ℚ_in_ℂ
                .   apply Subfield.subset_closure
                    apply Set.mem_singleton

                have h8 : (2 : ℂ) = 1 + 1
                .   ring

                rw [h8]

                /-
                Identifier <missing> not found
                -/
                apply Subfield.add_mem ℚ_in_ℂ h7 h7
        sorry
    h1

I wonder where can I find the usage of the tactics?
Hover over a tactic to see what it does
PS (reading on mobile) usually we only indent two spaces (which makes code much easier to read on mobile)

Thanks

Kevin Buzzard said:

PS (reading on mobile) usually we only indent two spaces (which makes code much easier to read on mobile)

Thanks. My vscode used to give 2 spaces indents, but from yesterday it suddenly changed to 4, don't know why.

image.png

Hovering over 'have', the explanation seems pretty incomprehensible. Am I doing it wrong?
That's definitely not about have
Hovers are sadly completely unreliable when you have a syntax error

Yaël Dillies said:

Hovers are sadly completely unreliable when you have a syntax error

image.png

Thanks. After fixing the syntax error, it seems better, but it still doesn't show how many arguments it takes, what types the arguments should have, and how I should continue after the tactic. Also why does it say "An extension of the have tactic" when I'm hovering over 'have' itself?

On the blue bar at the bottom of VS Code there's a number 4, change it to 2. For questions like "what's the syntax for a common tactic" an easy way to find out is "just search mathlib for the many uses of that tactic and you'll find one which is helpful"
because there are secretly several have tactics, and this one is declared here and says " An extension of the have tactic that turns the hypothesis into a goal to be proved later"
It's a silly docstring. We should fix it
Regarding "things don't work very well when there's a syntax error", to paraphrase the old joke -- "well don't have a syntax error".

Kevin Buzzard said:

Regarding "things don't work very well when there's a syntax error", to paraphrase the old joke -- "well don't have a syntax error".

Thanks. But the main reason I want to see the docstring is because I have a syntax error.
Yes I suppose so! Point taken!

My vscode used to give 2 spaces indents, but from yesterday it suddenly changed to 4, don't know why.

Is this just after opening VS Code? If so, it might be vscode#231224 and closing / re-opening the tab should also fix it.

(now at a computer)

import Mathlib

example : 2 + 2 = 4 := by
  have foo : 1 + 1 = 2 := by norm_num
  have : 3 + 3 = 6 := by norm_num -- this fact is now called `this`
  have bar : 4 + 4 = 8 := by
    norm_num -- indent 2 for longer proofs
  norm_num -- proves the example finally

Thanks. I wonder why '.' can replace ':= by'?

Kevin Buzzard said:

(now at a computer)

import Mathlib

example : 2 + 2 = 4 := by
  have foo : 1 + 1 = 2 := by norm_num
  have : 3 + 3 = 6 := by norm_num -- this fact is now called `this`
  have bar : 4 + 4 = 8 := by
    norm_num -- indent 2 for longer proofs
  norm_num -- proves the example finally

aprilgrimoire said:

Thanks. I wonder why '.' can replace ':= by'?

Kevin Buzzard said:

(now at a computer)

import Mathlib

example : 2 + 2 = 4 := by
  have foo : 1 + 1 = 2 := by norm_num
  have : 3 + 3 = 6 := by norm_num -- this fact is now called `this`
  have bar : 4 + 4 = 8 := by
    norm_num -- indent 2 for longer proofs
  norm_num -- proves the example finally

I think this just works with the tactic 'have', and with the term proof 'have' , because you go into tactic mode for each have anyway.

Thanks. I wonder why '.' can replace ':= by'?

After have name : Statement you have a new goal, so why not allow \. as a syntax? This is a common syntax when you have more than one goal.

Kevin Buzzard said:

Thanks. I wonder why '.' can replace ':= by'?

After have name : Statement you have a new goal, so why not allow \. as a syntax? This is a common syntax when you have more than one goal.

Thanks. I think my confusion comes from not knowing lean is a space-relevant language.
aprilgrimoire has marked this topic as resolved.
